p: Today, due to the growing environmental awareness, the scientific community and manufacturers have focused their attention on flax fiber, as it is the most widely used bio-fiber in composite materials [ 6]. Flax fibers and other bio-fibers are used as ecological alternatives to glass fiber in composites for engineering applications [ 7]. In 2010, 13% of the total reinforcement materials were bio-fibers, while a forecasting up to 2020, states that this percentage will be higher than 28% [ 8]. Bio-fibers, such as flax, have a potential as a raw material in composites used in building industries, sport equipment, packaging, paper, furniture, and automotive industries [ 9]. The chemical composition of flax fiber, as reported by several authors (about 64%–74% cellulose, 11%–17% hemicellulose, 2%–3% lignin, and 1%–2% pectin, 1.5% waxes, and 8%–10% water) allows an optimal equilibrium between mechanical and ductile properties [ 10, 11].
